column4: I'm doing it by zcat > boot.img.gz > /dev/sdf1
The USB drive is 2GB and formatted to fat16
As soon as I copy stuff with zcat , it strangely becomes 16MB and I can't fit the .iso on it !
Before doing zcat boot.img.gz > /dev/sdf1 , the partition is 2.0GB big
after doing zcat, it magically becomes 16MB
I did it this way with Debian before, and it worked. And I'm following a guide from help.ubuntu.com so there's no excuse for this to not work.
do you have a CruZer stick?
yea, ScanDisk makes them. I thought that maybe it had security on it like the CruZer
: And the moral of the story is ... ?

honestly dude if you are looking for help. you could start chillin out. The moral of the story is that CruZer disk's have a security on their filing system that doesnt allow certain things.. details im not sure of. but it shouldnt effect you in your case
no its not, thats why I just wanted to knwo what type of disk it was

: So let's assume the stick doesn't allow certain things. It is possible because earlier it didn't boot when I used another method . Could I brute-force just install Kubuntu on it  ?  Would that work ? I need to boot kubuntu NOT from cd, because I need to copy 1xcd  + 1xDVD to my Debian partition. For some reason Asus P5K SE motherboards have big problems detecting CDROm in linux.
you could try formatting the disk under Ubuntu with gparted
